column4: Basically right across the street from Macleod's -- I'd check here first, as the prices are usually a bit better and I don't think this store is exactly thriving (hmm....coincidence?).

Probably my favourite Indian place in town -- a bit of a weird location, but they deliver! The chili chicken, the paneer makhani, and the fish pakoras are all EXTREMELY notable. So good I miss it even in Montreal, where there's no shortage of good Indian restaurants.

Really great Malaysian food, especially if you like fish. They make this spectacular -- no, transcendent! -- green bean dish with shrimp paste and tomatoes. It's pretty popular, so I'd recommend making a reservation. Truly worth busing your ass out to.
Not a HUGE selection, but the prices are reasonable, the owner is nice, and the cat is cute. Worth browsing if you're in the neighbourhood.
Your best bet in Gastown. I like this café because they have more substantial fare than just paninis and muffins, and they're licensed. Good for a power lunch.

This place has cute sandwiches that are just like mom probably used to make, and they serve everything with a handful of chips or cheetos on the side. It's a bit of a hidden treasure in the wasteland of downtown.

Big, long established consignment store. Feels not unlike a teen bedroom. Can be a bit hit or miss, but it's fun to sort through. They're the kind of place that has a huge selection of evening gloves, rhinestone jewelry, and funny old hats. You know?

This place is nothing to write home about really, but it's my hole in the wall greasy spoon of choice. Old-timey dinerish feel, low lights, and they usually play oldies. Good hangover remedy, and the crazy Eastern European ladies who own it are amazing.

This is my favourite new book store in town. They have a great selection, and the people there are really nice/helpful/happy to order anything in. Has that crucial "neighbourhood" vibe, and you can tell they're very passionate about what they do. Which is great. Because I, too, am passionate about books.

Reliably nice clothing with a focus on local design. The clothes here can be a bit expensive, but they generally stock the well made, classic kinds of pieces that you can justify dropping some coin on.

Cagibi? What are you doing here in Vancouver? Seriously, though, Finch's is an old favourite of mine for a coffee and a slightly overpriced (but delicious) baguette sandwich. It's a really pleasant space, especially if you can get a window seat.

column2: Lunch, Dinner, Open late, Mount Pleasant
column4: There are a lot of things I dislike about this place: pseudo-political quotes painted on the walls, peanut butter pasta (what?!), and the general Funky-Vegetarian vibe. But. There are two extremely important things I really, really like about The Foundation: the nachos are phenomenal, and they're open late. Seriously. Crucial!

Big consignment shop, spanning three storefronts. I think they have a tiny men's section, but I've never known a guy to have a sweet find here. Sooo, this recommendation is Ladies Only. Right before I left town, a huge portion of the building was lost to a fire, but they should probably be up and running again by now. Surely!

My favourite coffee place in this neighbourhood. It's a really pleasant space, their snacks are tasty, and, honestly, they probably serve the best coffee I've had in Vancouver. Great place to stop and read/work in for an afternoon.

My favourite Ethiopian place in town. They make their own honey wine, their vegetarian dishes are tasty, and their meat dishes are EXCEPTIONAL. There are other great places on Commercial further down (Addis and Harambe), but this one's worth the extra walking. They're occasionally closed at strange times, though.

The Best Shoe Store In Town. Hands down. Occasionally a bit too "funky," often much, much too expensive, they're still the first stop on any well thought out shoe quest. There's a "Gravity Pope" clothing store right next door, too, which is generally worth a look.

column2: Dinner, Drinks, Snacks, Open late, Downtown
column4: Wonderful, wonderful Japanese tapas -- I've never had a bad thing here, and I've probably ordered everything on the menu at one point or another. Trust me, everything's good. Even (especially?) the more "western" dishes like the lamb hamburg steak. Each location has a slightly different menu/vibe, but I recommend them all heartily.

column2: Dinner, Drinks, Snacks, Open late, Downtown
column4: More wonderful Japanese tapas. The decor at this place feels a bit more "hip" and "trendy" than Guu, but it offers very similar fare: sashimi, salads, things wrapped in bacon, creamy desserts, and the like. The patio's nice if, miraculously, it isn't raining.

column2: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Drinks, Commercial Drive
column4: The local opinion of this place is resoundingly that it is not as good as it used to be, but the tapas are still tasty, they still make a mean breakfast, people still swear by their sangria, and the patio is still heated and enjoyable for people (and dog) watching.
Cheap, cheap, delicious, cheap, delicious Malaysian food. Cheap and delicious. No, but really.

Best street meat in town! They make hot dogs with "Japanese" style toppings: wasabi mayo, teriyaki, seaweed, etc. Also, they claim Ice Cube ate there TEN times! That's an endorsement you can't ignore.

There are actually about a million JJ Beans in Vancouver, all with great coffee, but this is the only one I -really- like, maybe because it's a couple blocks from my old apartment. It's also just more relaxed and quiet than the others. It's also got a very comfy, very worn in couch. It's also the only location where you can watch them roast the beans (fascinating!).
Good place to drink Italian coffee and get cat called. There are a bunch of other great Italian coffee shops in this neighbourhood, but this is the one I went to the most for whatever reason.

My favourite Mexican place in town. It's in a bit of a sketchy neighbourhood, but is by no means a sketchy establishment. It's really not easy to find decent Mexican in Vancouver, so discovering this place was a very exciting thing for me.

I don't usually go out for Italian food (can't I make speghetti at home?), but I came here for a work lunch once and it was really amazing. It's in the Italian Cultural Centre, so you can count on everything being prettttty authentic. Their funny "opulent" 90s decorating scheme is also a big bonus.

A very well curated clothing shop: some local, some imports, mostly chosen with tailoring in mind. Healthy sized men's section, nice, helpful employees. The space is really beautiful, too -- worth checking out just for that!

Like Sha Lin, will BLOW YOUR MIND. Handmade noodles (get the dish with the garlic and lemon infused oil, please, so I can live vicariously through you), life changing dumplings...I once ate here three days in a row, and easily could have made it a fourth.

This place is "kid friendly," which means a lot of things: the tables are spaced well apart, there's a play area, and it's completely packed with hippie moms on the weekends around brunch time. The food is great, but I heartily recommend you go there during the less-busy hours. Unless you LOVE kids and the noise they make.

All the other used bookstore owners in town absolutely hate this place, but I think this has more to do with the owner than the store itself. It's enormous, chaotic, and most likely has whatever it is you're looking for. A bit overpriced, though -- I suspect they keep up their customer base by hiring only super cute nerd girls.

One of the few genuinely good dining places on the Drive -- it's not a hole in the wall or a hidden treasure, just a nice, clean restaurant you can take your Mom (or your date) to. It's Mexican-inspired (I won't say fusion), but a bit more adventurous than the usual bean/rice/cheese fare.

This is truly a hidden gem in a bleak-ish area of downtown Vancouver. The space is really beautiful, the coffee's great, and the food is, well, really special. You can sit in the cafe for a coffee and a waffle, or you can eat in the restaurant space out back. Both experiences are highly recommended. Pretty sure brunch is only on weekends.

Decent vintage store, with a slightly weird (and occasionally unfortunate) selection of new/locally made/cheap clothes as well. Last I heard, they were going out of business, but through some sort of magic they still seem to be around. For now.

Little French style (or, more accurately, French -themed-) cafe, great for a crepe and a glass of wine. Your waitress (the proprietor) will probably be wearing a beret. They occasionally have terrible open mic or jazz shows, but if you can avoid those, the atmosphere is quiet and enjoyable.

column2: Dinner, Snacks, Drinks, Open late, Mount Pleasant
column4: Aptly named! It's a tiny, narrow, narrow, narrow space, so it can sometimes be a bit tricky to get a table. Look for the red light -- I don't think there's a sign. They have a really impressive drink list and great comfort food/snacks, and every time I go there, I feel I've stumbled on a magical hidden treasure.
This is an amazing cheap/fast/filling Lebanese place. One of my favourite lunch spots in town -- it has a pleasant atmosphere, and every single thing on the menu is just delicious.
This is an amazing cheap/fast/filling Lebanese place. One of my favourite lunch spots in town -- it has a pleasant atmosphere, and every single thing on the menu is just delicious.

This was my favourite place to stop for a morning coffee/snack when I worked around here. They specialize in WAFFLES! Sweet waffles, savoury waffles, custard-filled waffles, waffle sandwiches, waffles beyond your wildest dreams! Their non-waffle pastries are exceptional, too. Can not recommend highly enough, if you're ever around 4th Ave or Granville Island.

Really easy to miss this place -- from outside, it basically looks like an abandoned building. Inside, it's quite a chic little cafe, though, and their specialty is "Yoshoku," which is basically Japan-ized western comfort food. Meaning: things deep fried, drizzled with mayo, and served in elegant little portions. It's great.

Looks unwelcoming from the outside, but great once you get in there. I've never eaten dinner here, but I know it's an option, and who knows?, maybe it's good. I can definitely promise drinks, though, not to mention the Portuguese guys trying to steal away any females from your table. Doesn't that sound great? It's great.

Stark, white -- basically looks like the inside of a Mac computer....so it should come as no surprise to be greeted by a little glowing apple on every table. The coffee's really good, though, so if you can't handle all the Macbook-clacking, just get it to go and wander to a park.

They usually have a pretty good selection, though they somewhat confusingly have separate sections for "literature" and (mostly Penguin paperback) "classics." Fairly reasonable prices, owned by nice peeps.

This place is great because it's a bit off the beaten Commercial Drive track so it's not quiiiite so busy in the weekend-brunch hours (though it is still pretty busy). It's also great because they're into the whole organics/local produce thing but they still serve meat. Some of their food is a bit bland at times, but most things are delicious. Hangover plus: it's painted very soothing colours.

Not the easiest place to find: it's located in an alley, and they only signage is a salt shaker. All they have here is charcuterie, cheese, bread, wine and port -- I know this SOUNDS a bit intimidating, but it's not upscale or overpriced at all, trust me. The staff are really helpful, knowledgeable, and enthusiastic, too, which really adds to the experience. Highly, highly, highly recommend.

Oh MAN. If you are ever around Granville Island at lunch time, go here for SURE. It was my favourite lunch place when I worked around there. A small, unassuming place with simple, delicious Japanese food -- rice balls and donburi -- made very well. They have a huge tea selection and try to use all organic ingredients. I always feel very happy after eating here.

I've only been here a couple times because it is nowhere near where I used to live, but their brunches are really tasty if you can stomach the "funky" Vancovuer aesthetic. They serve their eggs benny on biscuits -- I mean, come ON!

Will BLOW YOUR MIND. Truly authentic Chinese restaurant -- you can watch the chefs hand spin the noodles while you wait. Generally pretty busy, especially at lunch, but worth the wait. Not a fancy place at all.

Wonderful, cozy whiskey bar with an insane selection. They share a building and a kitchen with The Irish Heather (so if whiskey's not your thing...go there instead!). The staff here really know your stuff, so you'll probably end up trying something you've never had (or heard of) before. Mmm.

Great Indian food. A friend of mine once found a cockroach on a table here, but she loved the food so many she kept coming back anyways. I don't know if that's really going to sell it to you, but, you know. Full disclosure.

column2: Dinner, Snacks, Drinks, Open late, Gastown
column4: This place is always a very solid bet for a drink and a bite, though it gets pretty busy on weekends. It's a really pleasant space, they have a HUGE selection of imported beers, they make a mean whiskey sour, and their (ever-changing) food menu is reliably tasty.

This place is designed with our demographic in mind, which frankly I always find a bit grating. It's a nice place, though, and a good bet for a tasty breakfast probably served by a hot waitress. If it's too full, go to "Nice Café" around the corner.

column2: Coffee, Snacks, Dinner, Drinks, Mount Pleasant
column4: This is a good place for a quiet coffee, a quiet drink, or a quiet meal. They have a bit of a "wine bar" vibe, but it doesn't really come off as pretentious, just, you know, nice. The staff are all pretty knowledgeable, and the food's reliably good. An excellent choice when you've grown weary of recreational slumming.

This is a place where I take my parents when they visit. It's almost aggressively "funky," full of garage sale junk and bright colours and other such wackiness. But the food is actually pretty good -- sandwiches, burgers, the like -- so it's one of the best bets along 4th Ave. Don’t try to go for weekend brunch, though.

column2: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Drinks, Open Late, Downtown
column4: Okay, this is one of the only decent places to get a reasonable meal downtown. It has the look and menu of an old diner, but…updated (meaning, aged white cheddar in the mac-n-cheese and the occasional organic item). You will probably end up here before a concert or something, one day.

column2: Dinner, Snacks, Drinks, Open late, DTES
column4: Good selection of local beer, tasty (if slightly pricey) food. The vibe here can sometimes be somewhere between hip and douchebaggy: better to go on a weeknight, when it's a bit more relaxed. Worth checking out, though, despite the sketchy location.
Most reliably nice clothes in town -- the buyer has a discerning eye that I really trust. Bit pricey, though. Helpful, charming, and cute sales girls. I miss this store so much.

The old standby. Feels like someone's parents' 1970s basement: ugly mismatched couches, board games, weird paperback novels, fish tanks, and a cranky owner wearing bicycle shorts. Best to avoid the beer on tap (hangover city) -- I stick to bottles or whatever the whiskey special is. You can usually enter through the front door, but sometimes you have to knock on the back door in the Extremely Sketchy Alley.

By all appearances just a regular coffee shop/bistro style place, but somehow their soup du jour/paninis/sandwiches/baked goods are just a little bit extra delicious. If you make it in early enough, you can get one of their scones, which are so good they used to be the high point of each and every work day for me.

So, get this: it's an Irish pub, right, but it isn't entirely populated by idiots. And the food is actually great (Guinness braised beef pot pie is a favourite). This is a pleasant spot for a pint and a snack, though it's extremely busy on seemingly arbitrary nights, so proceed with caution.

column2: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Drinks, Commercial Drive
column4: Great Caribbean restaurant! They have excellent jerk chicken, roti, johnny cakes, etc., and a surprisingly impressive cocktail list. Honestly, I think they have more drink options than food choices. Great brunches, too, especially if you can get a seat on the patio (both locations are prime for people-watching).

Unfortunately, the vintage clothes here lean overwhelmingly toward the rock t-shirt/Hawaiian print side of things, but they also generally have a few hidden gems. The store is HUGE and they get some genuinely great stuff.
Try to overlook the name. No one seems to know about this place and it's super cheap. Right around the corner from Pulp Fiction.
